answers.explanation:
![](/content/media/neuro-3-2.webp)

In the right eye, there is optic disc pallor with adjacent horizontal radial retinal folds (black arrow) in the papillomacular bundle. In the left eye, there is hyperemic optic disc edema with optic disc hemorrhages and superior pallor. Retinal folds (black arrow) are also evident in this photograph.

questions.title: Question 2
questions.text:
![](/content/media/neuro-3-3.webp)

To further investigate the retinal folds, an OCT was performed in the area.  Based on the OCT, where are the folds located?

answers.explanation:
![](/content/media/neuro-3-4.webp)

You can see the retinal folds (red arrow) quite nicely on this OCT scan. Notice how the retinal folds are confined to the inner retina and do not extend to the outer retina and choroid. The retinal nerve fiber layer also appears thickened and edematous. OCT can be useful in distinguishing between choroidal and retinal folds. Retinal folds are a reported retinal manifestation of papilledema. Choroidal folds and peri-papillary wrinkles have also been reported to occur in cases of papilledema. For more details around this topic, please refer to the following paper:

Sibony PA, Kupersmith MJ, Feldon SE, Wang JK, Garvin M. Retinal and choroidal folds in papilledema. Investigative ophthalmology & visual science. 2015 Sep 1;56(10):5670-80.

questions.title: Question 3
questions.text:
On the raster protocol, there is an accompanying fundus photo that comes with the raster printout. To investigate the retinal folds, notice how the vertical raster lines have been applied to the area temporal to the right optic nerve where the retinal folds are most prominent. What type of ophthalmoscope was used to acquire this image?  

![](/content/media/neuro-3-5.webp)

answers.explanation: Many OCT machines today have built-in confocal scanning laser ophthalmoscopy technology allowing for operators to steer the OCT to image specific pathology, and to allow for side-by-side correlation of OCT scans with the corresponding fundus photo. When assessing a raster printout, make sure to refer to the accompanying fundus image.

questions.title: Question 4
questions.text:
![](/content/media/neuro-3-6.webp)

An OCT macula was subsequently performed demonstrating the following. What is the yellow arrow pointing to?

answers.explanation:
Separation of the retina from the underlying choroid by sub-retinal fluid (yellow arrow) is seen in the sub-foveal area. Development of macular sub-retinal fluid in the context of papilledema has been reported in the literature and hypothesized to occur due to a direct communication between the macular sub-retinal space and the swollen optic nerve.

For more information around this topic, please refer to the following paper: Hoye VJ, Berrocal AM, Hedges TR, Amaro-Quireza ML. Optical coherence tomography demonstrates subretinal macular edema from papilledema. Archives of ophthalmology. 2001 Sep 1;119(9):1287-90.

questions.title: Question 5
questions.text:
![](/content/media/neuro-3-8.webp)

After the VP shunt was placed, the patient was seen in follow-up and a repeat OCT macula of the right eye was performed, shown above. The orange arrow is pointing towards the ellipsoid zone. Why does it have this appearance?

answers.explanation:
Similar to CSCR, resolution of chronic sub-retinal fluid can cause changes and disruption of the ellipsoid zone (orange arrow), leading to poorer visual outcomes.

The OCT below demonstrates another patient with sub-retinal fluid (A) secondary to papilledema. When the sub-retinal fluid resorbed (B), there was subsequent disruption of the outer retina and the ellipsoid zone. The red arrows are pointing towards the accumulation of waste products in the photoreceptor outer segment of the detached retina. This has traditionally been referred to as a “brush border pattern”. The separation of the neurosensory retina from the RPE prevents the photoreceptor waste products from being processed by the RPE. If the waste products persist, they may become permanent sub-retinal deposits (blue arrow) after sub-retinal fluid re-absorption.

![](/content/media/neuro-3-9.webp)
